Overview.Description: The Level Editor provides the core level creation functionality for Unreal Editor. It is used to create, view, and modify levels by placing, transforming, and editing the properties of Actors.

KeyConcepts.Description: A 3D environment in which game experiences are created.
Any object that can be placed in a level, with 3D position, rotation, and scale data.

DefaultInterface.Description: The interface is customizable, but the default layout includes several key components.

TabBar.Description: Displays the name of the current level. Other editor windows can be docked here for quick navigation.
Details: Reflects the level currently being edited.
Tabs named after current assets being edited.
Current project name displayed to the right.

Toolbar.Description: Displays a group of commands for quick access to commonly used tools and operations.
Toolbar.Details: See Toolbar documentation for more details.

MenuBar.Description: Provides access to general tools and commands. It includes a console for entering special commands.

Modes.Description: Enable specialized editing interfaces and workflows for particular types of Actors or geometry.

Modes.Name: Select
Modes.Description: Activate Select mode to select Actors in your scene.

Modes.Name: Landscape
Modes.Description: Activate Landscape mode to edit Landscape terrains.

Modes.Name: Foliage
Modes.Description: Activate Foliage Mode to paint instanced foliage.

Modes.Name: Mesh Paint
Modes.Description: Activate Mesh Paint mode to paint vertex colors and textures on Static Mesh Actors.

Modes.Name: Modeling
Modes.Description: Activate Modeling editing mode.

Modes.Name: Fracture
Modes.Description: Activate Fracture mode to create destructible objects and environments.

Modes.Name: Brush Editing
Modes.Description: Activate Brush Editing mode to modify Geometry Brushes.

Modes.Name: Animation
Modes.Description: Activate Animation editing mode.

Viewport.Description: Your window into the worlds you create in Unreal Engine.
Details: Contains viewports that can be maximized to fill the entire panel.
Displays the world in orthographic or perspective views.

DetailsPanel.Description: Contains information, utilities, and functions for the current selection in the viewport.
Details: Transform edit boxes for moving, rotating, and scaling Actors.
Displays all editable properties for selected Actors.
Quick access to additional editing functionality.

Outliner.Description: Displays all Actors within the scene in a hierarchical tree view.
Details: Select and modify Actors directly from the Outliner.
Use the Info dropdown menu for additional columns like Levels, Layers, or ID Names.

BottomToolbar.Description: Contains shortcuts to the Command Console, Output Log, and Derived Data functionality. Displays source control status.

LayersPanel.Description: Allows you to organize Actors in your Level.
Details: Quickly select and control visibility of groups of related Actors.
Useful for decluttering scenes and managing modular parts.

EditorViewports.Description: The Viewports are your window into the worlds you create in Unreal Engine. They can be navigated just as you would in a game, or can be used in a more schematic design sense as you would for an architectural blueprint. The Unreal Editor viewports contain a variety of tools and visualizers to help you see exactly the data you need.

UsingEditorViewports.Description: Basic concepts and features of the Viewports in Unreal Editor.

Details.Introduction: The Viewports are your window into the worlds you create in Unreal. They can be navigated just as you would in a game, or can be used in a more schematic design sense as you would for an architectural Blueprint. The Unreal Editor viewports contain a variety of tools and visualizers to help you see exactly the data you need.

ViewportTypes.Description: There are two main types of Viewports in Unreal Editor: Perspective and Orthographic.

Types.Perspective: A 3D window into the game world.

ViewportLayout.Description: By default, you see a single Perspective Viewport when you open Unreal Editor.
ViewportLayout.DefaultLayout: The Viewport panel contains multiple Viewports, laid out in a grid with a default layout of 4x4, consisting of Perspective, Top, Front, and Side views.

Controls.Minimize: Minimize Viewport button located in the top right corner of each Viewport.
Controls.Maximize: Maximize Viewport button located in the top right corner of each Viewport.

ViewModes.Description: The Unreal Editor viewports have a large number of visualization modes to help you see the type of data being processed in your scene, as well as to diagnose any errors or unexpected results.

CommonModes.Lit: Shows the scene with full lighting.
CommonModes.Wireframe: Shows the scene as a wireframe model.

ViewModes.Access: All view modes can be accessed from the View Mode menu within the viewport.

GameView.Description: Game View causes the Viewport to display the scene as it would appear in the game, hiding editor-specific elements.
GameView.Enable: Press the G key (by default) with the Viewport focused or choose the Game View option from the Viewport Options menu.

ImmersiveMode.Description: Immersive Mode maximizes the Viewport to the full extents of the window containing the Viewport panel, enabling a full-screen editing experience.
ImmersiveMode.Enable: Press the F11 key (by default) with the Viewport focused or choose the Immersive Mode option from the Viewport Options menu.
ImmersiveMode.Restore: Press the F11 key again or the Restore Viewport button located at the top right of the Viewport when in Immersive Mode.

ViewportModes.Description: Explanations for the available View Modes within the viewports.

Details.Introduction: The Unreal Editor viewports have a large number of visualization modes to help you see the type of data being processed in your scene, as well as to diagnose any errors or unexpected results.

Modes.Name: Lit
Modes.Description: Shows the final result of your scene once all of the Materials and lighting have been applied.

Modes.Name: Unlit
Modes.Description: Removes all lighting from the scene, showing you Base Color only.

Modes.Name: Wireframe
Modes.Description: Shows all of the polygon edges in the scene. In the case of Brushes, you will see the resultant geometry.

Modes.Name: Detail Lighting
Modes.Description: Activates a neutral Material across the entire scene, using the normal maps of the original materials.

Modes.Name: Lighting Only
Modes.Description: Shows a neutral Material that is only affected by lighting, without normal maps.

Modes.Name: Light Complexity
Modes.Description: Shows the number of non-static lights affecting your geometry.

Modes.Name: Shader Complexity
Modes.Description: Visualizes the number of shader instructions being used to calculate each pixel of your scene.

Modes.Name: Stationary Light Overlap
Modes.Description: Displays overlap of stationary lights.

Modes.Name: Lightmap Density
Modes.Description: Displays the lightmap density of objects that are texture mapped, color-coding them by their relation to an ideal/max density setting.

Modes.Name: Reflections
Modes.Description: Overrides all materials with a flat normal and a roughness of 0, which is a mirror.

Modes.Name: LOD Coloration
Modes.Description: Displays the current LOD index of a primitive.

Modes.Name: HLOD Coloration
Modes.Description: Displays the Hierarchical LOD Cluster index of a primitive.

Modes.Name: Buffer Visualization
Modes.Description: Offers access to individual buffers within the graphics card to help diagnose scene appearance.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Base Color
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows only the Base Color of the Materials in your scene.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Decal Mask
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows in white any surface which can receive deferred decals.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Diffuse Color
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the result of Base Color and the Material's Ambient Occlusion inputs.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Shading Model
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the value of the Shading Model property for each Material in the scene.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Material AO
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the result of any texturing or Material Expression nodes connected to the Material's Ambient Occlusion input.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Metallic
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the result of any texturing or Material Expression nodes connected to the Material's Metallic input.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Opacity
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the result of any texturing or Material Expression nodes connected to the Material's Opacity input.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Roughness
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the result of any texturing or Material Expression nodes connected to the Material's Roughness input.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Scene Color
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the result of the scene before any post processing is done.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Scene Depth
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the depth of the scene in a constant gradient from white (farthest away) to black (closest).

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Separate Translucency RGB
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the color information of any Materials that are Translucent and using Separate Translucency.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Separate Translucency A
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows only the alpha information of any Materials that are Translucent and using Separate Translucency.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Specular Color
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the color being imparted to the specular reflections of a Material.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Specular
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the results of any texturing or Material Expression nodes fed into a Material's Specular input.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Subsurface Color
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the results of any texturing or Material Expression nodes fed into a Material's Subsurface Color input.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: World Normal
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the world space normal of any opaque surfaces.

BufferVisualizationModes.Name: Ambient Occlusion
BufferVisualizationModes.Description: Shows the result of any ambient occlusion calculations taking place in the scene.

LandscapeVisualizers.Name: Normal
LandscapeVisualizers.Description: Shows a Landscape in its normal, lit state.

LandscapeVisualizers.Name: LOD
LandscapeVisualizers.Description: Breaks a landscape up into color-coded panels representing their current LOD state.

LandscapeVisualizers.Name: Layer Density
LandscapeVisualizers.Description: Shows the landscape in a color-coded mode which shifts from green to red as more layers are added.

Exposure.Description: Exposure is a post-processing effect that controls the overall brightness of a scene. It can be set to a fixed value or left to automatic.

Types.Automatic: Adjusts the exposure dynamically as you move from light to dark areas and vice versa.
Types.Fixed: Locks the exposure in place to prevent automatic adjustments.

Viewport Show Flags.Description: Descriptions of all the available Show Flags for the viewports.

Flags.Name: Anti-aliasing
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the effect of anti-aliasing.

Flags.Name: BSP
Flags.Description: Shows/hides any Brushes in the level. (Alt + Q)

Flags.Name: Collision
Flags.Description: Shows/hides collision objects in the level. (Alt + C)

Flags.Name: Fog
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the effects of Height Fog. (Alt + F)

Flags.Name: Landscape
Flags.Description: Shows/hides any Landscape objects. (T)

Flags.Name: Navigation
Flags.Description: Shows/hides any Nav Meshes or other navigation Actors. (P)

Flags.Name: Static Meshes
Flags.Description: Shows/hides any Static Meshes in the scene. (Alt + W)

Flags.Name: Translucency
Flags.Description: Shows/hides all objects with translucent Materials.

Flags.Name: Bloom
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the effect bloom.

Flags.Name: Camera Imperfections
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the effect of Camera Imperfections.

Flags.Name: Color Grading
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the effect of Color Grading.

Flags.Name: Depth of Field
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the effect of Depth of Field.

Flags.Name: Lens Flares
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the effect of Lens Flares.

Flags.Name: Motion Blur
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the effect of Motion Blur.

Flags.Name: Tonemapper
Flags.Description: Shows/hides Tonemapper effects.

Flags.Name: Vignette
Flags.Description: Shows/hides Vignette effects.

Flags.Name: Directional Lights
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of lighting from the Directional Light actor.

Flags.Name: Point Lights
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of lighting from the Point Light actor.

Flags.Name: Sky Lighting
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of lighting from the Sky Light actor.

Flags.Name: Spot Lights
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of lighting from the Spot Light actor.

Flags.Name: Ambient Occlusion
Flags.Description: Shows/hides ambient occlusion in the scene.

Flags.Name: Diffuse
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of diffuse lighting in the scene.

Flags.Name: Direct Lighting
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of direct lighting.

Flags.Name: Dynamic Shadows
Flags.Description: Shows/hides dynamic shadows in the scene.

Flags.Name: Global Illumination
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of global illumination.

Flags.Name: Specular
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of specularity in the scene.

Flags.Name: Ambient Cubemap
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of the ambient cubemap.

Flags.Name: Distance Field Ambient Occlusion
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of AO generated from Distance Field meshes.

Flags.Name: Light Functions
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of light function materials on lights.

Flags.Name: Reflection Environment
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of the reflection environment.

Flags.Name: Subsurface Scattering
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the result of any subsurface scattering within the screen space.

Flags.Name: Volumetric Fog
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the volumetric fog.

Flags.Name: Detail Traces
Flags.Description: Shows detail traces.

Flags.Name: Far Field Traces
Flags.Description: Shows far field traces.

Flags.Name: Global Traces
Flags.Description: Shows global traces.

Flags.Name: Screen Traces
Flags.Description: Shows screen traces.

Flags.Name: Secondary Bounces
Flags.Description: Shows secondary bounces.

Flags.Name: AI Debug
Flags.Description: Shows the paths an AI-driven pawn is using to navigate.

Flags.Name: GBuffer Hints
Flags.Description: Colorizes objects that have improper Materials.

Flags.Name: Log Visualizer
Flags.Description: Draws any data to the screen required by the Log Visualizer system.

Flags.Name: Refraction
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the results of refraction on Materials.

Flags.Name: Test Image
Flags.Description: Shows a test image for monitor and graphics settings.

Flags.Name: Adaptive Depth of Field
Flags.Description: Applies a color coding filter for Depth of Field.

Flags.Name: Bloom
Flags.Description: Shows a visualization window for bloom effects.

Flags.Name: Distance Field Ambient Occlusion
Flags.Description: Shows a visualization of ambient occlusion from mesh distance fields.

Flags.Name: Motion Blur
Flags.Description: Changes the view to a Motion Blur visualizer.

Flags.Name: Screen Space Reflections
Flags.Description: Shows a visualization for Screen Space Reflections.

Flags.Name: Atmospheric Fog
Flags.Description: Shows/hides atmospheric fog Actors.

Flags.Name: Audio Radius
Flags.Description: Shows/hides the radius of audio Actors.

Flags.Name: Bounds
Flags.Description: Shows/hides bounds on selected objects.

Flags.Name: Constraints
Flags.Description: Shows/hides rigid body constraints.

Flags.Name: Foliage
Flags.Description: Shows/hides any Foliage Actors in the scene.

Flags.Name: Show All
Flags.Description: Shows all types of volumes in the scene.

Flags.Name: Hide All
Flags.Description: Hides all types of volumes in the scene.

Flags.Name: Audio
Flags.Description: Shows/hides Audio Volumes.

Flags.Name: Blocking
Flags.Description: Shows/hides Blocking Volumes.

Flags.Name: Camera Blocking Volume
Flags.Description: Shows/hides Camera Blocking Volumes.

Flags.Name: Show All
Flags.Description: Sets all Layers in the scene to be visible.

Flags.Name: Hide All
Flags.Description: Hides all Layers in the scene.

Flags.Name: Show All
Flags.Description: Shows all types of billboard sprites.

Flags.Name: Hide All
Flags.Description: Hides all types of billboard sprites.

Flags.Name: Characters
Flags.Description: Shows/hides Character billboard sprites.

Flags.Name: Effects
Flags.Description: Shows/hides Effects billboard sprites.

Flags.Name: Lighting
Flags.Description: Shows/hides Light Actor billboard sprites.

Flags.Name: Show All
Flags.Description: Shows all foliage types.

Flags.Name: Hide All
Flags.Description: Hides all foliage types.

Viewport Controls.Description: Learn about the various control schemes for the editor's viewports.

Perspective.LMB + Drag: Moves the camera forward/backward and rotates left/right.

Orthographic.LMB + RMB + Drag: Zooms the viewport camera in and out.

Focusing.F: Focuses the camera on the selected object.

Perspective.LMB + Drag: Moves the camera forward/backward and rotates left/right.

Focusing.F: Focuses the camera on the selected object.

Controls.Alt + LMB + Drag: Tumbles the viewport around a single pivot.
Controls.Alt + RMB + Drag: Dollies (zooms) the camera toward/away from a pivot.
Controls.Alt + MMB + Drag: Tracks the camera in the direction of mouse movement.

Controls.Description: Sensitivity of zoom and pan camera operations is scaled with the distance between the selected objects and the camera.

Controls.Enable: Level Editor > Viewports > Controls > Use distance-scaled camera speed.

Controls.Description: Camera orbits around the pivot of selected objects.

Controls.Enable: Level Editor > Viewports > Controls > Orbit camera around selection.

Actions.LMB: Selects the Actor under the cursor.
Actions.Ctrl + LMB: Adds the Actor under the cursor to the current selection.

Actions.LMB + Drag: Replaces the current selection with the Actors in the box.
Actions.Shift + LMB + Drag: Adds the Actors in the box to the current selection.
Actions.Ctrl + RMB + Drag: Removes selected Actors in the box from the current selection.

Actions.LMB + Drag (on Transform Tool): Moves, rotates, or scales the selected Actors.
Actions.MMB + Drag (on Pivot): Moves the pivot of the selection temporarily.

Actions.Alt + LMB + Drag (on arrows): Creates and moves a duplicate of the selected Actor(s).

Perspective Viewports.Ctrl + LMB + Drag: Moves the selected Actor(s) along the X axis.
Perspective Viewports.Ctrl + RMB + Drag: Moves the selected Actor(s) along the Y axis.
Perspective Viewports.Ctrl + LMB + RMB + Drag: Moves the selected Actor(s) along the Z axis.

Orthographic Viewports.Ctrl + LMB + Drag: Moves the selected Actor(s) along the plane defined by the two visible axes.

Actions.Ctrl + LMB + Drag: Rotates the selected Actor(s) along the X axis.
Actions.Ctrl + RMB + Drag: Rotates the selected Actor(s) along the Y axis.
Actions.Ctrl + LMB + RMB + Drag: Rotates the selected Actor(s) along the Z axis.

Actions.Ctrl + LMB + Drag: Scales the selected Actor(s) uniformly along all axes.

Orthographic Viewports.Ctrl + RMB + Drag: Rotates the selected Actor(s) along the visible axis.

Actions.Ctrl + R: Toggles real-time playback in the active viewport.
